The Lotto Protocol for Secure Participant Selection
• Offline Setup: – All parties are given the security parameter κ𝜅\kappa, the target number of sampled clients in a round s𝑠s, the current round index r𝑟r, the over-selection factor α𝛼\alpha, a range [0,m)0𝑚[0,m) to be used for PRF or VRF, the population threshold nm​i​nsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑖𝑛n_{min}, and a timeout l𝑙l. All clients also have a private authenticated channel with the server and the PKI, respectively. The server knows the exact population size n𝑛n. Client i{
  • –

    Generate a key pair ←(pkireg,skireg)KA.gen(pp) for signature and send the public key pkireg to the PKI for registration.

  • –

    Receive the secret key for Lotto’s use, skiLotto, from the PKI. Send the public key pkireg to the server for registration.

\textrm{{Client} \ }i\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Generate a key pair $(pk_{i}^{reg},sk_{i}^{reg})\leftarrow\textrm{{KA.gen}}(pp)$ for signature and send the public key $pk_{i}^{reg}$ to the PKI for registration. \par\itemize@item@[--] Receive the secret key for Lotto{}'s use, $sk_{i}^{Lotto{}}$, from the PKI. Send the public key $pk_{i}^{reg}$ to the server for registration. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Server {
  • –

    Receive all clients’ registration keys {pkireg}. Use them to query the PKI on the application public keys {pkiLotto}.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Receive all clients' registration keys $\{pk_{i}^{reg}\}$. Use them to query the PKI on the application public keys $\{pk_{i}^{Lotto{}}\}$. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • [Online Stage 0 (Population Refinement):]
Server { – Based on specific criteria, select n clients with the best utility from the population and take this set of clients as the new population. \textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Based on specific criteria, select $n$ clients with the best utility from the population and take this set of clients as the new population. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • Online Stage 1 (Client-Centric Selection):
Server {
  • –

    Announce to all clients in the population the beginning of round r and the population size n.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Announce to all clients in the population the beginning of round $r$ and the population size $n$. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Client i{
  • –

    Upon receiving the population size n, verify that ≥nnmin. Abort if it fails.

  • –

    Generate a random number =βi,πiVRF.evalskiLotto(r). Send to the server (βi,πi) and claim to join only if <βi/αsmn.

\textrm{{Client} \ }i\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Upon receiving the population size $n$, verify that $n\geq n_{min}$. Abort if it fails. \par\itemize@item@[--] Generate a random number $\beta_{i},\pi_{i}=\textrm{{VRF.eval}}_{sk_{i}^{Lotto{}}}(r)$. Send to the server $(\beta_{i},\pi_{i})$ and claim to join only if $\beta_{i}<\alpha sm/n$. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Server {
  • –

    Insert responding clients into the candidate set C and store their reported self-selection outcomes {(βi,πi)} until timeout after l.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Insert responding clients into the candidate set $C$ and store their reported self-selection outcomes $\{(\beta_{i},\pi_{i})\}$ until timeout after $l$. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • Online Stage 1 (Server-Centric Selection):
Server {
  • –

    For each client i in the population, compute =βiPRFpkireg(r) and insert the client into the candidate set C only if <βi/αsmn.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] For each client $i$ in the population, compute $\beta_{i}=\textrm{{PRF}}_{pk_{i}^{reg}}(r)$ and insert the client into the candidate set $C$ only if $\beta_{i}<\alpha sm/n$. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • Online Stage 2 (Client Verification):
Server {
  • –

    If <|C|s, abort the current round r. Otherwise, select s clients from C uniformly at random to form the participant set P≜{(i,pkireg,¯βi,πi)}. Broadcast to all participants ∈iP this participant set P and the used population size n.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] If $\lvert C\rvert<s$, abort the current round $r$. Otherwise, select $s$ clients from $C$ uniformly at random to form the participant set $P\triangleq\{(i,pk_{i}^{reg},{\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\underline{\beta_{i},\pi_{i})}}\}$. Broadcast to all participants $i\in P$ this participant set $P$ \lx@texthl@color{and the used population size $n$}. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Client i{
  • –

    Receive from the server a participant set Pi and query the PKI on the public key pkjLotto for each participant ∈jPi using pkjreg.

  • –

    Verify ∈(i,pkireg,¯βi,πi)Pi, =|Pi|S, ≥nnmin, <βi/αsmn and =VRF.val(pkj,r,βj,πj)1 (or, <PRFpkjLotto(r)/αsmn) for ∈∀jPi.

  • –

    Abort if any of the test fails. Sign the observed participant list Pi via =σiSIG.signskireg(r||Pi) and send the signature σi to the server.

\textrm{{Client} \ }i\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Receive from the server a participant set $P_{i}$ and query the PKI on the public key $pk_{j}^{Lotto{}}$ for each participant $j\in P_{i}$ using $pk_{j}^{reg}$. \par\itemize@item@[--] Verify $(i,pk_{i}^{reg},{\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\underline{\beta_{i},\pi_{i}}})\in P_{i}$, $\lvert P_{i}\rvert=S$, $n\geq n_{min}$, {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{$\beta_{i}<\alpha sm/n$ and $\textrm{{VRF.val}}(pk_{j},r,\beta_{j},\pi_{j})=1$}} \lx@texthl@color{(or, $\textrm{{PRF}}_{pk_{j}^{Lotto{}}}(r)<\alpha sm/n$)} for $\forall j\in P_{i}$. \par\itemize@item@[--] Abort if any of the test fails. Sign the observed participant list $P_{i}$ via $\sigma_{i}=\textrm{{SIG.sign}}_{sk_{i}^{reg}}(r\lvert\rvert P_{i})$ and send the signature $\sigma_{i}$ to the server. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • Online Stage 3 (Consistency Check):
Server {
  • –

    Collect signatures from participants in ⊆P′P and abort in case of timeout after l. Broadcast {j,σj}∈jP′ to each participant ∈iP′.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Collect signatures from participants in $P^{\prime}\subseteq P$ and abort in case of timeout after $l$. Broadcast $\{j,\sigma_{j}\}_{j\in P^{\prime}}$ to each participant $i\in P^{\prime}$. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Client i{
  • –

    Receive from the server the set {j,σj}∈jP′i.

  • –

    Verify =P′iPi and SIG.ver(pkjreg,r||Pi,σj)=1 for ∈∀jP′i. Abort on any failure, or refer to Pi as participants at round r hereafter.

\textrm{{Client} \ }i\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Receive from the server the set $\{j,\sigma_{j}\}_{j\in P^{\prime}_{i}}$. \par\itemize@item@[--] Verify $P^{\prime}_{i}=P_{i}$ and $\textrm{{SIG.ver}}(pk_{j}^{reg},r||P_{i},\sigma_{j})=1$ for $\forall j\in P^{\prime}_{i}$. Abort on any failure, or refer to $P_{i}$ as participants at round $r$ hereafter. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right.
Figure 3: A detailed description of the Client-Centric and Server-Centric protocol for secure participant selection in Lotto (section 3). [Italicized parts inside square brackets are additionally required for informed selection.]

references:
Specifically, to achieve secure random selection [50], Lotto allows each client in the population to
determine its participation in a training round by computing verifiable random functions (VRFs) [29, 51] using its secret key and public
inputs. Once a client decides to participate, Lotto collects the referred
randomness, along with the associated VRF proof, for other participants to
verify the generation of the randomness. This approach ensures that each
client’s participation is provably independent of, fair to, and unpredictable
for other clients. Yet, an adversarial server may still exploit this process
to grow the dishonest cohort, for example, by sending incorrect and/or a
selected subset of messages.
Lotto further mitigates such misconduct by enabling honest clients to verify critical messages.
Lotto provides a provable guarantee that the compromised fraction of selected participants remains minimum, thereby maintaining the security guarantees offered by secure aggregation and distributed DP (section 3.4).

Fortunately, while enforcing execution integrity could be complex, the server’s ability to grow the ratio of dishonest participants can still be controlled indirectly by reasonable use of parameters in Lotto.
To ensure that dishonest clients remain a minority among the participants, regardless of how the server removes honest candidates, it is sufficient to guarantee that the number of dishonest candidates x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime} is significantly smaller than the target number of participants s𝑠s.
This way, even if the server deliberately includes all dishonest candidates in the final participants, as long as the number of participants is required to be fixed at s𝑠s, the remaining participants, which constitute the majority, have to be honest clients.
To establish an upper bound for 𝔼​[x′]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑥′\mathbb{E}[x^{\prime}], we require a sufficiently large population size n𝑛n, because 𝔼​[x′]=c⋅α​s/n𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑥′⋅𝑐𝛼𝑠𝑛\mathbb{E}[x^{\prime}]=c\cdot\alpha s/n and all parameters cannot be manipulated by the server except for n𝑛n.
Thus, Lotto let honest clients agree upon a minimum acceptable population size, denoted as nminsubscript𝑛minn_{\text{min}}, and abort if the announced n𝑛n falls below this threshold.

Lotto Induces Acceptable Overhead in Time.  
Figure 8 summarizes the average round time in random selection, broken down into two parts: local training (‘train’), and the remaining workflow operations (‘other’).
It also shows the runtime portion of the latter, helping the reader understand the characteristics of various FL tasks.
When compared to Rand, Lotto implemented with Client-Centric incurs a time cost of less than 6%, 8%, and 10% for population sizes of 100, 400, and 700, respectively.
Moreover, the overhead for Server-Centric is 1%, 4%, and 3%, respectively.
Such acceptable overhead is expected as Lotto is built on lightweight security primitives (3.4).
As for informed selection, all the observed trends are identical to those reported in Figure 8 (with Rand replaced by Oort).
We thus defer the results to Appendix E for brevity.

Figure 13 and Figure 14 present a comparison between Lotto’s informed selection and Oort in terms of average time cost and network footprint at the server end during a training round, respectively. When compared to Oort, the Lotto implementation using the Client-Centric approach incurs a time cost of less than 5%, 10%, and 5% for population sizes of 100, 400, and 700, respectively. Additionally, the overhead for Server-Centric is 2%, 0%, and 0%, respectively. Regarding the network footprint, Lotto introduces less than 1% additional network footprint across all evaluated tasks and participation scales. The observed trend indicates that Lotto maintains an acceptable time cost and negligible network overhead during informed selection, similar to the findings in random selection (section 5.2).
